--- David Jared <dajared@...> wrote:
> 
> Personally, I think the separation of test and
> production code is the biggest limitation of JUnit
> and
> why I don't use it.  It's a "good thing" to have the
> tests for a class included in the class. The classes
> are self contained.  Why go back to the C++ days of
> having separate files for the same class: .h, .cpp,
> test.cpp. 
> 
> I'm sure different teams are have different work
> pactices, but when the tests are in a separate
> class,
> tests don't get updated/created.  The biggest
> impediment to creating unit tests was the need to
> crack open a separate test class.
> 
> Thanks,
> David Jared
> Distributed Workshop
> (303) 359-7190
> 
> 

I disagree.  It's a matter of making testing a habit. 


I've heard several arguments both for and against
having tests contained in the class they are
testing...so far I fail to be convinced that having
them separated is a bad thing.

When they are separate, the tests will get
created...if you make the effort.  And, stating that
this is a reason not to use JUnit, sounds like you
were just looking for a reason not to use it.  Try it
for a week or two...or for some small little project
you're working on (or piece of a project, whatever). 
I've found JUnit invaluable and use it both at work
and at home.  Coding without it seems now, to me,
counter productive.  But that's just me. :)


-Eric
